Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Extracting title attribute and linktext of an HTML-anchor

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Hi Christian,

With Heritrix 1.12 you can't give URI priorities, but you can give them prerequisites. This allows you to assign a URI to come before another URI. I think this is how it works, but I haven't looked much at that code, but it works more like a linked list then a ranking sort.

You are right that in Heritrix 2.0 they now support rankings of URIs, but I haven't looked at that either.

I would be interested in know if you get this implemented with 1.12, because that is a feature I'd like to use as well.

----- Original Message ----
From: Christian Krumm <signore.chrissi@...>
To: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, February 19, 2008 6:09:44 AM
Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] Extracting title attribute and linktext of an HTML-anchor










  


    
            Hi Mathew,



I think you misunderstands me a bit. What I want to do is extracting features

of a hyperlink, like the linktext or title-attribute.

I don't mean the title of the HTML-Page here.

Assumed we have an anchor like this:

<a href="http://www.google. com" title="Google Homepage">Google</a>



I wan't to extract the URL, the title "Google Homepage" and the
Linktext "Google" so I can calculate a prediction how relevant a
webpage is, before downloading it.

I also need the possibility of priorisize or delay  extracted URI
candidates, so relevant pages can be considered first (a.k.a Focused
Crawling). In Heritrix 2.0 there exists an attribute precedence which
should do the job implementing an own UriPrecedencePolicy , I think. But
actually I don't really know it, because heritrix2 isn't released and
neither a developer manual nor a documentation of the precedence
feature exists. 



Is there a (similar) mechanism to priorize or delay URIs in Heritrix 1.x ?



Thanks a lot for your help.



Greetings from Oldenburg (Oldb) / Germany

Christian








2008/2/19, Mathew Nik Foscarini <nfoscarini@yahoo. com>:













  


    
            
Hi Christian,

The
ExtractorHTML class is used to add URIs to the queue waiting to be
crawled. Since the title tag is not a valid URI it doesn't help to
extract that tag in a modified version of that class. You could write
your own writer class to store the title, and other tags to a file or
database for that URI.

You can extract the title tag using a regular expression.

"(?i)(<title>.*?</title>)"

As an example.

    <div id="ygrp-text">
            <p>Hi Mathew,<br>
<br>
I think you misunderstands me a bit. What I want to do is extracting features<br>
of a hyperlink, like the linktext or title-attribute.<br>
I don't mean the title of the HTML-Page here.<br>
Assumed we have an anchor like this:<br>
<a href="<a rel="nofollow" target="_blank" href="http://www.google.com">http://www.google. com</a>" title="Google Homepage">Google</a><br>
<br>
I wan't to extract the URL, the title "Google Homepage" and the
Linktext "Google" so I can calculate a prediction how relevant a
webpage is, before downloading it.<br>
I also need the possibility of priorisize or delay  extracted URI
candidates, so relevant pages can be considered first (a.k.a Focused
Crawling). In Heritrix 2.0 there exists an attribute precedence which
should do the job implementing an own UriPrecedencePolicy , I think. But
actually I don't really know it, because heritrix2 isn't released and
neither a developer manual nor a documentation of the precedence
feature exists. <br>
<br>
Is there a (similar) mechanism to priorize or delay URIs in Heritrix 1.x ?<br>
<br>
Thanks a lot for your help.<br>
<br>
Greetings from Oldenburg (Oldb) / Germany<br>
Christian<br>
<br>

ExtractorHTML class is used to add URIs to the queue waiting to be
crawled. Since the title tag is not a valid URI it doesn't help to
extract that tag in a modified version of that class. You could write
your own writer class to store the title, and other tags to a file or
database for that URI.<br><br>You can extract the title tag using a regular expression.<br><br>"(?i)(<title>.*?</title>)"<br><br>As an example.<br><br><div style="font-family: times new roman,new york,times,serif; font-size: 12pt;">
